1. The common cold includes nasal congestion, runny nose (discharge can be clear or yellow-green), sore throat, cough, fatigue, low grade fever, sneezing and headache.
2. The common cold lasts from 3-10 days and longer in smokers.
3. The common cold is differentiated from viral or allergic nasal inflammation by the presence sore throat and cough.
4. The common cold can be differentiated from bacterial tonsillitis (pharyngitis or tonsil infection) by the presence of runny nose and nasal congestion.
5. No antibiotics are needed to treat the common cold.

6. Pharyngitis (infection of the throat and glands) symptoms include sore throat, fever, fatigue, swollen neck glands, and +/- watch patches at the back of the throat. Usually pharyngitis requires antibiotics.
7. If there is no fever but there is a cough with pharyngitis symptoms, no antibiotics are needed.
The common cold can cause and lead to sinusitis, lower respiratory tract infection, asthma exacerbation and ear infections.
Acute sinusitis includes symptoms of facial pain, clear or yellow-green nasal discharge, nasal obstruction.
The most common cause of acute sinusitis is viral infections. Therefore no antibiotics are recommended unless patient has fevers >102 or other risk factors.
Acute viral sinusitis is expected to improve within 10 days without the use of antibiotics. Nasal discharge starts clear but may turn yellow-green later in the illness.
Acute bacterial sinusitis lasts longer than 10 days, causes high fevers (>102), and nasal discharge is yellow-green within the first 3 days of illness.
Acute bronchitis includes cough, sputum production and lasts at least 5 days. Wheezing and shortness of breath are also symptoms of acute bronchitis.
Influenza symptoms include high fever, cough, headache. muscle and body aches. Antivirals are recommended to treat influenza.
Pertussis is similar to the common cold but has prolonged coughing and will require antibiotics.
The majority of upper respiratory infections are transmitted by hand contact. Viruses remain alive on human skin for 2 hrs. therefore hand washing is important to prevent the spread of disease.
